James,

The current design provides testRunStarted(int count) and
testRunFinished(Runner runner) notification to TestListeners. Is this
sufficient for your purposes or do you need to be notified when a class'
tests are about to be run and have finished running?

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> 
> Hi Barry,
> 
> This has been discussed
> here<http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/14389>.
> I'm not sure how much help that will be for your particular case.
> 
> That's the third time that I've seen this come up, and JUnit 
> 4 is still in
> gestation, so I'd like to take this opportunity to ask anyone 
> involved with
> developing it on their thoughts on this problem. I do prefix 
> this with the
> caveat that I haven't yet looked at JUnit4 or Java5 beyond 
> reading Elliotte
> Rusty Harold's developerworks article, so please be gentle with me.
> 
> My solution essentially involved adding startSuite and endSuite method
> signatures to TestListener and then modifying TestResult to 
> accept Observers
> that implemented this new interface and report when the 
> particular lifecycle
> events occured. The implementation was just a first draft and could
> doubtless be made more robust - my tests were just enough to 
> get it up and
> running.
> 
> I'm aware of Kent's stated intent that JUnit should be the 
> intersection of
> test tool functionality rather than the union (somewhat 
> paraphrased!), but
> I'd be interested in hearing everyone's views about where 
> this functionality
> should live. Presumably the logic to maintain a hierarchy of 
> TestSuites must
> be reimplemented by all tool vendors interested in displaying 
> a tree of the
> results, rather than a core part of JUnit. Is that the right 
> place for it?
> As a counter argument, I can see that if a vendor implemented a
> multithreaded TestRunner for running TestSuites concurrently, then
> maintaining a hierarchy might be a little interesting using 
> my simplistic
> implementation.
> 
> James
